At Wed, 09 Jul 2008 15:32:17 -0700,
Craig McClanahan <craigmcc@...> =
wrote:
> Agreed that it's just a convention, and that neither is "standard"=
 in 
> any sense.  But there is (at least) one important consideration that=
 
> might affect your choice of one format versus another ... caching.  The=
 
> format that includes the identifier in the URI itself, such as:
> 
>   =
  http://localhost/MyResources/{Id}/State
> 
> offers you the opportunity (=
if you set your cache control headers 
> correctly) to let the data for eac=
h particular value of {Id} to be 
> cached by an intermediary between you a=
nd the client, while the 
> parameter based format:
> 
>     http://localho=
st/MyResources/State?id=3D{Id}
> 
> does not, because request parameters ar=
e not considered part of the key 
> under which caching occurs.

Do you hav=
e an example of a cache which exhibits this behavior? The
subtleties of web=
 caching have often eluded me, but I=E2=80=99ve never heard
this before, an=
d it=E2=80=99s not part of 2616, as I read it.

best,
Erik Hetzner
